title: Google to Restrict Political Ad Targeting on Its Platforms
summary: Advertisers will no longer be able to target political ads based on users' interests inferred from browsing or search history. Alphabet Inc.'s Google said Wednesday it plans to stop allowing highly targeted political ads on its platform, further fragmenting the rules being set by Silicon Valley tech giants for guarding against misinformation.

title: Federal Watchdog Confirms FAA Facility's Air Traffic Hazards
summary: Procedures stay in place more than a year after risks cited by a whistleblower are verified. Air-traffic controllers at a Federal Aviation Administration facility that tracks planes across parts of Florida and four other states are using questionable and unsafe procedures that increase risks of midair collisions, according to the government office that vets whistleblower complaints for federal agencies.

title: PayPal's Latest Deal Could Yield a Bonanza for Small Investors
summary: The payments platform is looking to buy Honey Science, an online coupon startup, for $4 billion. Several small Los Angeles area investors are set to make a bounty if payment company PayPal Holdings Inc. 's $4 billion purchase of local startup Honey Science Corp. goes through.

title: U.S. Defense Chief Says Ligado Spectrum Plan Would Degrade GPS
summary: Defense Secretary Mark Esper urges federal regulators to reject Ligado's wireless license application. U.S. Secretary of Defense Mark Esper urged federal regulators to deny Ligado Networks LLC's proposal to develop some of the nation's most valuable airwaves, saying the risks to global positioning systems and military operations are too great.

title: Sondland Says He Pursued Ukraine Probes at 'Express Direction' of Trump
summary: Ambassador to EU criticizes Giuliani, links Pompeo more directly to the pressure campaign. title: In Bolivia, Violence Surges as Political Crisis Mounts
summary: After protesters were killed in clashes with security forces, government blames ex-leader Evo Morales for inciting his backers to block food and fuel from cities. LA PAZ, Bolivia-Bolivia's political crisis is deepening as state security forces use increasingly lethal force against mobs of protesters demanding the return to the country of former President Evo Morales, whom the country's interim government accuses of stirring up the trouble.

title: PayPal to Buy Honey Science for $4 Billion
summary: PayPal executives say the shopping platform will help deepen engagement. PayPal Holdings Inc. has reached a roughly $4 billion deal to buy shopping and rewards platform Honey Science Corp., as it pushes to gain a bigger role in consumers' shopping habits.

title: As New York Faces Big Medicaid Cost Overruns, Cuomo Stays Mum
summary: Officials pass their legal deadline to release a midyear budget report, leaving some concerned about the governor's plans for the health program. New York's Medicaid program expenses are running at least $3 billion over budget, but the administration of Gov. Andrew Cuomo has so far said little about its plans to deal with the issue.

title: Sondland's Unimpeachable Offenses
summary: Witnesses are providing more detail about what we already know.. The House impeachment hearings roll on, but the most important news is how little new we are learning about President Trump and Ukraine. The witnesses from the diplomatic and national-security bureaucracy are filling in some details-many of which are unflattering about how policy is made in this Administration-but none change the fundamental narrative or suggest crimes or other impeachable offenses.

title: What's Your Degree Worth?
summary: The Education Department offers some valuable college data.. For many Americans a college degree will be among the most expensive investments they ever make, one reason they have compiled $1.5 trillion in student-loan debt. The Education Department hasn't made the price go down. But on Wednesday Secretary Betsy DeVos relaunched a website that will help people get a better idea of what they are buying before they begin writing those big tuition checks.

title: Union Labor's Profanity Protection
summary: Should picketing workers be able to shout racist remarks with impunity?. Union workers can say a lot while under the protection of American labor law. For example: "Go back to Africa, you bunch of -ing losers!" That was only one of the racial epithets shouted in 2012 by picketing Ohio tire workers at a group of replacement employees, many of them black.

title: General Motors Files Racketeering Lawsuit Against Fiat Chrysler
summary: Lawsuit against auto maker involves its relations with UAW officials; GM says it will ask for damages. General Motors Co. accused Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV of bribing union negotiators to gain a competitive advantage, triggering an unusual legal dispute between crosstown rivals by filing a federal racketeering lawsuit.

title: Oil Rallies as Stockpiles Rise Less Than Expected
summary: Crude prices snap a two-session decline after government report on inventories. Oil prices rose Wednesday, snapping a two-session streak of declines after a weekly government report showed a smaller-than-anticipated rise in U.S. crude-oil inventories.

title: The Impeachment Kangaroo
summary: The Pelosi-Schiff impeachment shows what has gone so badly wrong with Washington.. title: FedEx Delivers Billions to the Taxman
summary: The New York Times runs a misleading story on our 2018 tax return. Here's the real story.. As a corporate citizen, we decided many years ago to engage openly in four areas of public policy that have strategic implications for our company and the more than half a million people who work for us: energy, the environment, trade and taxes.

title: The Campaign Data Arms Race
summary: The GOP reclaimed its supremacy in 2016. Can the Democrats come back in 2020?. An arms race is under way that will deeply affect America's future. It's not about next-generation nuclear weapons or hypersonic missiles. Instead, it's a struggle between Republicans and Democrats over who has the best political data. In this emerging digital age, elections hang in the balance.

title: Progressives Ambush the Salvation Army
summary: The group touts its efforts to help sexual minorities, but the left isn't satisfied.. The Salvation Army is the latest target of progressive wrath. British pop singer Ellie Goulding threatened to cancel an appearance at the Dallas Cowboys' Thanksgiving halftime show, which will celebrate the army's red-kettle campaign, unless it made a "pledge or donation to the LGBTQ community." She backed down after the Salvation Army assured her it serves needy members of that community. Chick-fil-A this week said its charitable foundation will no longer donate to the Salvation Army and two other organizations that hold traditional views on same-sex marriage-apparently yielding to intense political pressure.

title: How to Answer Chinese Atrocities in Xinjiang
summary: The West can impose sanctions on Communist officials and companies that use slave labor.. The documents implicate the highest officials in the country, and make the strongest case yet for global sanctions.

title: 'Oblivion or Glory' Review: Churchill the Deal Maker
summary: Churchill's deal creating an Irish Free State was called a betrayal by his unionist allies. But the debate it settled had consumed U.K. politics.. In 2005 James Shapiro published "1599: A Year in the Life of William Shakespeare." It was a decided success, winning the Samuel Johnson Prize for best nonfiction book. Since then many biographers have become fond of the device of seizing on a critical year in the life of a great man. David Stafford's important work "Oblivion or Glory: 1921 and the Making of Winston Churchill" is an elegant venture into this field. Its power lies in a vivid re-creation not only of Churchill's public roles but also his private life-of good fortune but also family tragedy-thus producing something close to the actual rhythm of lived history.

title: Israel Faces New Vote Prospect After Coalition Talks Fail
summary: Ex-military chief Benny Gantz's failure means the country is likely headed for a third election in a year. TEL AVIV-Former military chief Benny Gantz failed to form a government by his Wednesday deadline, raising the likelihood of a third election in a year while prolonging Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's rule and political uncertainty in the country.

title: Iran Says It Has Contained Protests, but Tensions Persist
summary: Economic pressures from U.S. sanctions have led to simmering frustrations. Tehran used arrests, deadly force and a prolonged internet blackout to contain nationwide protests that pose the most serious test in years for Iran's leaders.

title: Trudeau Turns to Trade-Deal Lieutenant to Quell Tension Over Energy
summary: Former Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland, who led talks with Trump administration, also takes on deputy PM role. title: Blackouts Return to Northern California
summary: PG&E shuts off power to around 48,000 customers because of elevated fire risk. SAN FRANCISCO-Northern California endured its fourth round of blackouts in two months amid high winds, a new norm as the state's utilities try to prevent deadly wildfires.

summary: Justice Department updated language in its Foreign Corrupt Practices Act Enforcement Policy. The U.S. Justice Department made several clarifications to its foreign bribery leniency program, in a move officials said was part of a continuing initiative to be transparent to companies.

title: U.S. Grants Some Exceptions to Huawei Blacklist
summary: Trump administration eases restrictions on suppliers to blacklisted Chinese telecom giant amid slowdown in negotiations. title: Warren's '2 Cents' Will Prove Costly for All
summary: The burden of taxing unrealized capital gains will fall on a vastly greater number of people than a wealth tax on the super wealthy.. Regarding Andy Puzder's "Warren's '2 Cents' Come at Your Expense" (op-ed, Nov. 12): Faced with surrendering effective control of their business decisions and assets, many corporations will choose inversions (i.e., merging with foreign corporations), restructure their supply chains or use transfer pricing mechanisms to minimize their U.S. presence. Meanwhile, rapidly growing young, midsize companies (think: Google in 2002, Starbucks in 1996 or Cisco in 1992) will have to move control and other key functions offshore to preserve their ability to innovate freely. Faced with annual taxation on their wealth, the truly wealthy will do what they have always done, i.e., domicile their money where its treated best. Investment in illiquid and unproductive assets will be encouraged at all income levels. Finally, venture investing will diminish because IPOs (used for exiting investment) won't be viable in the event a real winner develops.

title: We Have the NATO Most Europeans Wanted
summary: Today, our NATO allies are largely debellicized, and have plundered their defense budgets to fund social welfare programs and pensions.. Regarding Walter Russell Mead's diagnosis "NATO Isn't Dead, but It's Ailing" (Global View, Nov. 12): Our NATO allies have finally created the alliance that they have worked for over decades.

title: Many Teachers Can Get Help Buying Houses
summary: The teacher he uses as an example could obtain an FHA loan with only 3.5% down.. Regarding Michael P. Carter's letter of Nov. 13 on the increasing unaffordability of houses for single teachers: It would be foolish to wait years to save for a 20% down payment. The teacher he uses as an example could obtain an FHA loan with only 3.5% down. That same teacher could obtain an interest-free second mortgage, with no payment required, as down-payment assistance, courtesy of the taxpayers in Georgia. (Mr. Carter is from Georgia but most, if not all, states have assistance programs). The teacher can finance the entire price plus most of the closing costs. He or she can also ask the seller to contribute to the closing costs. A significant portion of the low- to moderate-income borrowers don't need any money of their own to buy a house.

title: Canada Inflation Stays Close to 2% in October
summary: Third straight month annual inflation climbed at 1.9%. OTTAWA-Canada's annual inflation rate rose in October and for a third straight month at a pace just shy of the Bank of Canada's 2% target.

title: Food-Delivery Services Taxed by Duty Question
summary: Grubhub CEO says rivals aren't paying enough in sales taxes, but differing state laws and business models complicate the analysis. Grubhub Inc. Chief Executive Matt Maloney says his food-delivery rivals need to charge more sales taxes on their delivery fees. They disagree.

title: Qualcomm Stacks All Its Chips on 5G
summary: Company sees chipset business driving future growth as licensing expected to stay flat. Qualcomm Inc. has long been 5G's loudest proponent. Now the company has to make the next-generation wireless technology pay off-in a big way.

title: Beijing Summons U.S. Diplomat to Protest Support for Protesters
summary: Move follows Senate unanimously approving bill requiring annual certification of Hong Kong's sufficient independence for favored trading status. BEIJING-China's Foreign Ministry summoned the highest-ranking U.S. diplomat in the capital to object to Washington's support for Hong Kong protesters, a day after Beijing asserted its authority to rule on Hong Kong's constitutional issues.

title: Teachers Lament Loss of Grammar. Some Students Say It Ain't a Problem.
summary: Time constraints, emphasis on hands-on projects and state tests leave little time for study of English structure, some educators say. A master class in grammar for New York City teachers started with laughter over misplaced commas in local newspapers.

title: Hospitals Push Back on Price-Disclosure Rule
summary: Industry groups vow to challenge Trump administration proposal requiring disclosure of secret payment rates. Hospitals are pushing back against the Trump administration's new health-pricing disclosure rule, with the industry planning a legal challenge to block it.

title: No Assigned Seats, and Other Rules of the Perfect Friendsgiving
summary: Because Friendsgiving is always more fun than Thanksgiving. Holiday-loving chef Jonathan Waxman's six tricks for hosting the most successful one yet. Between the two, we're more thankful for Friendsgiving than actual Thanksgiving. A Friendsgiving dinner, where guests are friends or colleagues instead of family, allows for more invention and experimentation than its more traditional counterpart. "Cooking is the antidote to stress," says chef Jonathan Waxman. "We all deserve to pamper ourselves a little bit." Waxman, 69, the chef behind New York restaurants Jams and the now-closed Barbuto, is known for bringing his take on California cooking to the city, in particular with his famous roast chicken with salsa verde. His approach to Friendsgiving, like the one he hosted at Empire Diner in New York earlier this month, is the same as his overall philosophy: Keep it simple. "Don't try to do too much," he says. Below, Waxman, who recently released his own holiday dinner kit in collaboration with Grey Goose and A-K Hada, who designed cocktails, shares his best advice for having a stress-free, festive Friendsgiving dinner.

title: It Is Time for African Countries to Shed Monetary Colonialism
summary: Eight sub-Saharan nations are openly talking about scrapping the CFA franc, which could eventually unlock some of their economic potential. Imagine being forced to invest all of your money in French stocks in exchange for having the euro as your base currency. That is the predicament many countries in sub-Saharan Africa are now trying to escape.

title: James Harden: The Most Fouled Man in the NBA
summary: The Rockets star is on pace to break the NBA record for free throws. Can he sustain this pace?. James Harden specializes in doing things that most NBA players have never done and never been able to do.

title: Mainland Chinese Investors Pile Into Hong Kong Despite Unrest
summary: The city's shares trade at cheaper valuations than those in Shanghai and Shenzhen. Investors from mainland China have plowed nearly $20 billion into Hong Kong's stock market in less than six months, focusing on cheap valuations despite long-running unrest.

title: Evo Morales Offers to Sit Out Bolivia's Next Election
summary: Interim government and military are unlikely to trust that former leader won't want to stay in power if he returns, analysts say. MEXICO CITY-Evo Morales, the exiled former president of Bolivia, said he is willing to sit out the country's next presidential election if he can finish the last few months of his term and, together with the opposition, name a new electoral authority to oversee a fresh vote to choose a new leader.

title: HSBC Investment Bank Chief to Move Aside
summary: Long-serving executive Samir Assaf will take up a non-executive role as part of broader management reshuffle. LONDON- HSBC Holdings PLC is parting ways with another long-serving executive, investment bank head Samir Assaf, in a reshuffling of its management team that could see more division heads leave the bank.

title: Labour Strongholds Are in Play in U.K. Elections
summary: Resume Subscription. WORKINGTON, England-If Boris Johnson is to win next month's national elections and take Britain out of Europe, his party needs to win over swing towns like this one, which got rich in the 19th-century industrial revolution but have been left behind in the 21st.

summary: Former American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault on how to jump-start progress on racial diversity and change he hopes for in Silicon Valley.

title: Fed Minutes to Shed Light on Internal Debate Over Rates
summary: Minutes may also reveal officials' conclusions about September's money-market volatility and potential fixes. The Federal Reserve releases the minutes of its Oct. 29-30 meeting on Wednesday at 2 p.m. EST, shedding light on its decision to cut interest rates and signal a wait-and-see policy stance.

title: China's New $21 Billion High-Tech Manufacturing Fund Likely to Rankle U.S.
summary: The Trump administration has criticized China for subsidizing the technology and advanced manufacturing sectors. China set up a $21 billion fund to further develop its advanced manufacturing sector, demonstrating that Beijing is pursuing its ambition to lead globally in technology, despite U.S. criticism of subsidies.

title: Thai Court Rules Pro-Democracy Party Leader Violated Electoral Law
summary: Potentially more troubling for the Future Forward Party are the trials to come. One lawsuit alleges party links to the Illuminati.. A Thai court dealt a setback to a pro-democracy opposition leader, effectively stripping him of his status as a lawmaker in the first ruling to come out of a string of legal cases against him and his political party.

title: Shinzo Abe's Record and the Continuing Revolution in Japanese Stocks
summary: The overhaul that came with Abenomics transformed the country's listed companies, and still has more to offer. Under Shinzo Abe, who became Japan's longest-serving prime minister on Wednesday, structural economic reforms helped lift the country's stock market.

summary: Chinese e-commerce giant raises $11.2 billion in secondary listing with auspicious numbers. Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. has pulled off a blockbuster Hong Kong stock sale even as protests rage in the city, in a deal packed with auspicious numbers.

summary: A wildly overpriced stock that has rallied 3,800% this year could end up in the portfolios of global index investors. Coming soon to your index funds: a $5.9 billion unprofitable Chinese marble miner that has rallied 3,800% this year.

title: Pope Francis Takes Nuclear-Ban Mission to Japan
summary: Pontiff expected to pursue disarmament and interreligious dialogue on visit to Asia. Pope Francis is expected to call for world-wide nuclear disarmament this week during an Asia tour that will feature visits to the atomic bomb sites in Nagasaki and Hiroshima, Japan.

summary: Health care likely to remain biggest policy split among the 10 White House hopefuls, meeting for their fifth contest. Ten Democratic presidential contenders will meet in Atlanta on Wednesday. The Democratic National Committee's fifth debate will be broadcast on MSNBC at 9 p.m. E.T.

summary: Many airlines punt on the needs of overweight fliers and the people sitting next to them; Southwest is the exception. How can an airline be fair to two passengers when there's not enough room for both of them?

summary: Jerusalem retaliates with airstrikes on military targets, including Iran-linked site. TEL AVIV-Israel's military said it struck dozens of targets in Syria after four rockets were fired toward the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights on Tuesday.

title: Bank Accused of Breaching Money Laundering Laws-More Than 23 Million Times
summary: Westpac, Australia's second-largest bank, failed to carry out due diligence on 12 customers with known child-exploitation risks, Austrac said. Australia's second-largest bank has been accused of the biggest breach of the country's money laundering and terrorism financing laws in history, including failing to detect transfers that may have been used to facilitate child exploitation in Asia.

title: The Fact Is, Democratic Candidates Use a lot of Filler Phrases
summary: Biden leads Democratic pack in using bits of speech that help candidates hold the floor. Here's the deal: Presidential candidates issue plenty of pointed barbs in debates, but they use a lot of filler language, too.
